poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Adding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001) - April 11, 2022

content.content: MIP39c2-SP32: Adding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001)  Preamble MIP39c2-SP#: 32 Author(s): @PonJerry, @Leggevents Contributors:  @Hexonaut, @Nadia, @tadeo, @juan Tags: core-unit, cu-events-001, proposal, mandate, active Status: Accepted Date Applied: 2022-03-09 Date Ratified: 2022-04-25 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip39c2-sp32-adding-events-core-unit-events-001/13780 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmSVzGcm   Sentence Summary MIP39c2-SP32 adds the Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001) to coordinate and execute MakerDAO branded events at Crypto/DEV Conference locations.  Paragraph Summary The Events Core Unit will handle planning, organization, and execution of MakerDAO branded events.  Our vision is to use an exhaustive list of themes, visuals, set dressing, technology and branding to carry out events to the highest standards for the MakerDAO community.  Specification  Motivation  The Absence of Maker It has been identified that MakerDAO currently has no event presence at crypto conferences.  This lack of presence has a negative impact on Maker’s brand.  Maker as a Household Name MakerDAO must have an outward presence at crypto events.  This must be a more strategic approach than previous events.  The events must include outward branding of Maker and its products creating a unique experience utilizing various set dress branding techniques such as physical logos, artwork, LED light installations, branded visual content, projection mapping, and digital promotion.  Everyone who attends the event will leave knowing they were at a MakerDAO event. An additional advantage of these events will be the large and highly visible brand awareness towards the crypto developer community in attendance.  Core Unit ID EVENTS-001  Core Unit Name Events  Core Unit Mandate  Mission To provide the best MakerDAO branded event experience to the crypto & Maker community including industry professionals, influencers, and enthusiasts.  Vision EVENTS-001 is a team of passionate creative professionals with extensive experience in event organization and a high level of technical experience in LED Lighting, Visual Installations/Animation, and branding. The team will leverage these skills to elevate the industry knowledge and awareness of MakerDAO and its products through a series of events held at various international locations.  Strategy The Events team approach is to execute 5 MakerDAO events per year.  Three of these events will be considered “major” events.  A major event is targeted at high attendance conferences.  The major events will focus on new branded themes utilizing visual animations, LED lighting installations, projection mapping, LED logos, and internationally recognized artists.  Apart from the organization and promotion of the event, there will be a high focus on seamless integration of visuals, lighting, and music to create a high-level event experience. Also included in our strategy are two “minor” events.  The target of these events is to host at a time in between major events.  The focus will still be outward branding, music, and visual elements but will be a scaled-down version of the major events.  The team would reuse visual themes and LED elements from the major events.  The musical element would utilize a local artist to keep the cost and scale of the event down. Branding visuals is a large focus of our strategy at these events.  Some examples of these elements the team plans to implement at the events are as follows:  BPM sync branded visual animations for use with LED video panels or traditional projection LED branded logos Synchronized LED wristbands to the visual and music elements 3D LED pixel mapping,  create the effect of a 3D hologram type effect which will include branding elements Addressable LED lighting installations Projection mapping of branded elements Complete synchronization and integration of LED Logos, house lighting, and installations with visual and music elements   Launch Pad The events can also serve as a launch pad for new Maker products.  The Events CU can assist the promotion of products by adding the branding or incorporating the product launch into the theme.  During the event planning, we would work closely with any CU’s which wish to take advantage of this to assist in the success of their product launch.  Event Documentation  Photos Event documentation plays a big part in contributing to the CU strategy. For each event, a photographer will be hired to photograph the night/attendees. The photos will be used for event recaps and future promotion on social media platforms. An example of these photos can be found here, which were captured from the Maker ETH Denver event.  Videos For Major events, a videography team will be hired and coordinated to capture the event. The based output from the videographers will be  3 fully edited recaps of the night. A one-minute recap and two- thirty-second recaps.  These would be used on social media as a post-event recap and also for future event promotion.  The video team hired for the Maker ETH Denver event produced the following three videos. One-minute recap: Maker Daivinity Promo 1 - YouTube Thirty seconds recap 1: Maker DAIvinity Promo 2 - YouTube Thirty seconds recap 2: Maker DAIvinity Promo 3 - YouTube  Pilot Event  ETH Denver Summary During the 2022 ETH Denver conference, the first MakerDAO branded event “DAIvinity” was trialed at The Church Nightclub to great fanfare.  The team planned and executed an event full of Maker branding including LED logos, digital Maker & DAI branded animations to the attendance of 1.000 people.  Additionally two internationally recognized DJs were curated for the night, Miss Monique & Sean Tyas.  Since the event, the buzz from the community has been unanimously lauding, with Bankless even giving the event a formidable shout out.  Venue ETH Denver gave a great opportunity to host the MakerDAO event at the famous Church venue.  The venue is internationally acclaimed and recognized in the DJ community.  1334×1999 180 KB   LED Branding The event included strategically placed Maker and DAI LED logos throughout the venue.  964×1280 177 KB   699×816 542 KB   Visuals & LED Bracelets  The Church featured LED video screens throughout the entire venue, offering the team a great branding opportunity for MakerDAO.  At the DAIvinity event, the team hired and coordinated with a visual animator to create custom Maker & DAI branded animations as well as a library of more abstract sequences for the night. Mapped to video screens lining the main venue floor on 3 sides the visuals created a panoramic experience that was controlled live through the entire event to closely sync the music, visuals, and custom procedural effects and content. In addition to the visuals, DMX-controlled LED bracelets were given to the guests.  These LED brackets were completely synced with the music and the colours of the visual content.  The bracelets can be seen featured in the recap videos.  2022/2023 Planning To achieve the CU mandate of 3 major events and 2 minor events the following are the proposed locations for the 2022/2023 fiscal year.  Major Events The major events are targeted to the largest attended conferences.  These have been identified as the following;  ETHCC - July 19-21, 2022 DEVcon (Bogotá, Colombia) - Oct 11-14, 2022 ETH Denver - Feb 2023  Note that these locations are only proposed and not final.  If CU’s agree that a major event should be moved to another conference then the Events CU will update accordingly.  CU’s will need to request a change of location with a minimum of 3 months in advance due to the logistical planning required for a major event.  Minor Events The 2 minor events are planned in between the major events.  The Events team will consult closely with the Maker community and other Core Units to determine the most effective locations. Attendance to minor conferences is uncertain until 1 to 2 months before the conference so the Events team will have to adjust accordingly.  During the incubation of this Core Unit, ETH Amsterdam was identified as a minor event location.  The event is currently being planned and executed during the date range of April 20-24, 2022.  Partnerships The Events CU plans to leverage partnerships with other protocols for these events.  The partnerships will allow for cross-promotion and cost offsetting of the CU budget.  From the cross-promotion aspect Maker will be able to tap into the partners’ audience,  this will allow for broader exposure and interaction with a different audience Maker may draw by itself.  The partners for the event would be expected to cost split the event sub budgets with the Events CU.  The split ratio would be discussed before the event during the planning phase.  Maker would always retain a majority share to ensure the event is Maker focused.  Creative and operation control would always remain with the Events CU.  An example of the potential cost reduction impact to the CU budget is highlighted in the DAI budget MIP40c3-SP66 under the Partnerships section.  Core Unit Team The Events CU team has been carefully curated to include expertise and skills to execute the ambitious vision of the MakerDAO events.  First and foremost is precision organization and execution of all aspects related to the events.  The Event Manager must be highly effective at communication and planning while remaining flexible to accommodate and resolve any unforeseen issues during the event execution.  The Event Manager will be the first point contact for event personnel and contractors.  This will ensure communication is consistent, clear and effective. The goal of the Events team is to be as vertically integrated as possible which is why the team has included a mechanical engineer role in the CU.  The engineer will be responsible for all technical aspects and coordination of visual elements, LED lighting and other event installations.  The engineer will additionally be responsible for the design and manufacturing of set dress, including LED lighting.   Safety analysis of rigging/installations would be performed by the engineer to ensure compliance with any local safety requirements or authorities.  The Events Team (FTE)  Event Manager: John Legg - Forum: @Leggevents  Facilitator/Mechanical Engineer: Jon Perry - Forum: @PonJerry       Role FTE     Event Manager 1   Facilitator/Mechanical Engineer 1     Role Definitions  Core Unit Facilitator  Communications with Governance and MakerDAO Community Managing budget and strategy Facilitate payment to CU members and contractors   Event Manager  Manage planning, design, production, promotion and overall coordination within the CU’s mandate Coordinate with Maker community to determine event dates Propose and coordinate event theme requirements to the CU’s team and contractors Develop a risk management plan for each event Oversee the financial management of event sub budgets Manage event contractors to ensure a seamless event Interface and coordinate with artist management Coordinate with social media personal Analyze the event’s success and prepare reports The Event Manager will also share responsibility with the Mechanical Engineer as required   Mechanical Designer/Engineer  3D Design & manufacturing of LED light installations, logos and other visual elements Build set dress as defined by Events team through means of woodworking, CNC machining/programming, electrical wiring Wiring and programing of DMX lighting elements Prepare technical drawings of a 3rd party set dress required Technical calculation required for set installations (load calculations, power requirements) Work with local bodies to ensure proper permitting and engineer signoff of event installations Coordinate with visual design to ensure seamless integration of visual elements, event lighting and music Procurement of set dress supplies The Engineer will also share responsibility with the Event Manager as delegated

content.content: MIP55c3-SP3: ETHAmsterdam Event SPF RFC   MIP55c3-SP3: ETHAmsterdam Event SPF  Preamble MIP55c3-SP3: Author(s): Jon Perry Contributors: @PonJerry, @hexonaut, @Saint.Burban, @juan, @Nadia Tags: Status: RFC Date Applied: 2022-03-09 Date Ratified: yyyy-mm-dd Amount Requested: 50,000 DAI Recipient Address: Multisig address will be added after successful on-chain vote prior to the executive vote.   Sentence Summary The purpose of this sub proposal is to allocate 50,000 DAI for the MakerDAO event in Amsterdam scheduled between April 20-24 20…     You may see the costs in this SPF proposal to produce the event above ($80,000.00 / event). You may compare them to the proposed core unit budget proposal ($250,000.00 / event) to see the per event cost discrepancies (+$170,000.00 / event). You can also see there is no comparable solicitation or market comparables from other providers in that spf request. The core unit proposal and budget includes the additional cost of full time Dai wages and a significant MKR budget for two parties.The core unit budget retains two people full time to produce events for the DAO. They are paid at market rate on top of actual production costs, which we presume are comparable to that EthAmsterdam SPF proposal. It seems a bit unorthodox to hire two people full time to do events. Not saying it isn’t a lot of work, simply that, the usual arrangement would be an outside contractor managed by existing CU/ CU budget or a SPF fund.  Note, this is the exact structure we see above and used to great success. This approach is a better fit,  has more appropriate costs and does not burden the DAO with ongoing obligations. Why fix something that isn’t broken? Core units come with obligations. We just saw the headache of offboarding a core unit, let’s be pragmatic in reviewing core units. Core units are one tool in our toolbox. No need to use a hammer on a screw when we have a screwdriver. If there are more reasonable ways to structure arrangements to meet our objectives, let’s do that.

content.content: @Doo_StableLab, let me address your questions; “Why does the team want to be a CU instead of consulting entity?” Post-DAIvinity there was a discussion with some of the Maker team of the best direction forward to continue hosting Maker events.  The scope of the events being planned requires a full-time commitment from the team.  One original proposal was to incorporate the budget and team into an existing core unit.  It was determined due to the scope of budget and already high workload of existing CUs that the best path forward is to create a new CU.  That way we can have a secure budget and full focus on these events. “In terms of budget, thank you for the detailed break down. Adding together, it comes out to be around $250,000 per event… Is this industry standard?” I’m not quite sure how your $250,000 per event figure was derived.  If you look at our proposed DAI budget the annual total with contingency is $898,150.  The contingency is there only to act as an emergency buffer.  For the following calculation, I will remove the 15% contingency as more than likely this will be returned to the DAO.  What I calculate is 781,000 divided by 5 events, $156,000 in a nutshell.  Now, this is presented as a worst-case scenario, there will be opportunities to save during the event planning.  One example was at DAIvinity the artist budget was $20,000 and after negotiation with the artist management the cost ended up being $15,000. Also as I mention on the budget MIP there is the possibility to partner with other protocols for these events.  We can determine their share of the expense and offset the cost of the event.  Any unused funds would be returned to the DAO. “Maybe the team mentioned in the proposal but in case where big events are difficult to host especially due to external factors like a new pandemic, would the team modify the budget to be smaller?” Yes if there is the issue of a new pandemic/strain that affects the ability to host larger events then we can determine the best strategy forward such as scaling down events and adjusting the budget accordingly.  As @jenn touches on in the post below the budget/events can be scaled due to unforeseen circumstances.  Ideally, this is not the case and at this point, we remain positive and plan for a world transitioning into the post-pandemic.

content.content: @MakerMan DAIvinity was allocated a budget of 80k;  here is a summary breakdown of the budget vs actuals.  I can provide a more detailed line by line if you would like but would need some time to convert to a Markdown table.     Category Budget Amount (DAI) Actual Amount (DAI)     Travel (5 People) $4,500.00 $5,471.98   Accommodations/Food (5 People) $3,500.00 $3,858.85   Set Dress (Venue Branding, LED Logos/Installations, DJ Equitment Rental, Lighting Rental, New Visual 3D & 2D Stock, Visual Renderfarm, Plugins/Software) $12,250.00 $12,026.71   Labor (Event Manager, 4 Contractors) $10,750.00 $10,750.00   Venue/Hospitality $25,000.00 $26,450.86   Music/Photography/Videography $20,000.00 $15,000.00   Misc (Shipping, COVID Tests, Onsite Tools/Equipment, Overhead $4,000.00 $5,530.00   Total $80,000.00 $79,088.40    There are a few things to note with this budget;   The labour paid is not aligned with the actual work put into this event.  As @hexonaut has stated we have been friends for many years.  The event scope started simply as a need to have an event at the ETH Denver conference.  @leggevents quoted his labour based on something simple.  After discussion with the maker team, the event concept quickly evolved into a larger scope than originally anticipated.  I ended up joining the event team to assist @leggevents.  I was paid as a contractor but again not the correct rate for the work that was involved.  To create DAIvinity it took @leggevents and me 3 months of solid work to organize and create the branding experience everyone witnessed.  This is not meant to be a complaint at all as there are no regrets from our end on the additional work as it has brought us to this proposal of continuing to support MakerDOA in future events.  I just want to highlight the effort and discrepancy you will see between this budget and the CU budget.  The CU budget has to be aligned to reflect the actual costs and labour of such events.   DAIvinity would be considered a major event under our proposal.  The sub budget for major events is 110,000.  30,000 higher than DAIvinity.  The reason is after reviewing costs from DAIvinity and anticipating future events I have allocated more money.  These events will be held in different locations around the world and potentiall more expensive cities.  As such higher costs of travel/accommodations, venue rental, currency exchange and contingency needs to be accounted for to have a one size fits all solution.  But in cases where we host another event at ETH Denver, it is anticipated that the event would not cost 110,000.  In turn, returning unused funds to the DAO.   I don’t have the breakdown of which CUs contributed how much.  @hexonaut would be able to provide this. "So how is this CU going to be able to function if it only gets 1/2 or 1/4 of the funding it wanted? Can it?" I assume this refers to the possibility of an extreme bear market where certain measures may need to be taken to protect MakerDAO by reducing budgets.  As a half budget, yes in theory this could be accomplished.  The result would have to be a scaled-back qty of events such as 1 major and 1 minor.  Or say 3 minor events you could get around 1/2 budget.  This would not be ideal from our perspective as the lower qty of events might not give Maker the same benefit as more consistent events. As a 1/4 funding in this situation, I would say no it would not work as FTE would have to be scaled back to part-time and in turn, could create an employee retention issue.

content.content: Events require advance notice, planning, and budgeting. What you write is definitely true. There is coordination and planning involved in securing a venue and managing other contractors. Hence, this is why defining a budget in advance specific to each event is necessary. Regardless of whether an internal or external party is planning the event, planning is required. This planning is complimentary with the use of an SPF and the appropriate proposal/RFP process. Using a proposal process secures fair economic terms for both Maker and the events vendor. No bid contracts are not normal in events. In any professional organization or under federal grants, you would be required to engage in a vendor selection process, which includes proposals, sourcing quotes, and a justification for the final selection. Any time a vendor is given a no bid contract, a sole source justification must be filed. These sole source justifications are the exception, not the norm, and are reviewed with scrutiny. There are a small set of circumstances where a sole source justification may be appropriate and a no bid process used. These are, for example, when there is a special skillset required, special technology, secret / top secret clearance, logistical constraints, etc. None of those conditions apply under a case like this for recreational commercial event production. MakerDAO does not need an events core unit. As far as this thread goes, there has still been no reasonable response as to why you need to be onboarded as a core unit, rather than as a vendor as you have been to date. Additionally,  the economics of the proposal do not seem to make sense as presented. These numbers are far off from your own past performance ($250,000 vs 80,000), and still inexplicable after you adjusted your previous numbers to meet the new proposed rates ($250,000 vs $156,000). To be more clear, this budget leaves $376,000.00 per year in additional compensation for two core unit members. Please bear in mind, this ~$376,000.00 of comp is in addition to your base comp, which is already included in the $156,000.00. These numbers would make you the best compensated nontechnical contributors in the DAO, beyond Gov Alpha, Risk, SES, etc. As you can imagine, these numbers are also quite far from market comparables for event production. Stick with what works and be positive. We have already seen positive results at a generous and practical spend from your proposed team. It does not make sense for Maker and MKR holders to lock in two full time employees on top of these production budgets.  Maker does not yet know its own demand for events. Moving forward, I would suggest continuing to use the SPF framework collaborating with other CU as you have been to great success. There is no evident business case under which this core unit proposal makes sense, especially when considering both the underlying economics and the actual present needs of MakerDAO. Your best bet to succeed is not to ride one early success, but instead to build a track record as a long term, reliable partner of the DAO.

content.content: Perhaps I can add some colour as someone who was involved with coordination for the previous event. First and foremost I would say that the status quo is unacceptable. Currently we have almost no presence at any of these events. At most a Maker-only event was being hosted (which was awesome and I loved it!), but these type of events do not help at all with outward brand presence. Furthermore these types of things need to be coordinated and organized by the other core units which often falls outside their mandate. The status quo leaves core units picking up the slack with teams that are already completely overworked. Being able to offload this work to a talented group is invaluable not only for doing a quality job, but also the resources it frees from other core units that were previously needing to deal with this out of necessity. It is my view that not only should we have an Events core unit, we should be looking to expand the team to cover all things involved with in-person events. We currently have no booths, no sponsorships, minimal speakers at all of these crypto conferences. This is very basic stuff that is currently falling through the cracks. If you haven’t worked in a company of this size before these numbers may seem large, but our expenditure on marketing and brand awareness is currently basically zero and this will increase it to only 1% of recurring revenues. This is still way outside the norm. I think it’s easy to write a post on here throwing out an idea of hiring contractors to do this, but who is actually going to do this? These sort of problems need to be solved now and we have 2 talented individuals who are here right now to solve this problem. Is the cost too much? I happen to think it is reasonable after seeing what was involved and the reaction of the people who attended, but obviously that can be debated. In general what the DAO needs right now is talent and a lot more of it. We do not get there by cutting costs. We get there by making strategic investments in people who can deliver quality results. I get that times are a little tough with the bear market right now, but I still happen to believe Maker is in a great position for the RWA explosion that is coming. We need to be preparing for 10x’ing our revenues instead of worrying about what is sustainable based on current revenues / expenses being projected out 4 years.

MIP40c3-SP66: Events Core Unit DAI Budget (EVENTS-001)   Partnerships The Events CU plans to leverage partnerships with other protocols to offset the event costs. Our goal for each event is to partner with other protocols to cost split. As an example 50%-MakerDao, 25%-Partner 1, 25%-Partner 2. MakerDao would always retain a 50% share minimum and have complete control over the creative direction and the event itself.   For 898,150 in budget to be justified, assuming stability fee of 3%, that will require 30 million Dai minted in vault to match the cost. And We have at max around 4200 + 1200 = 5400 attendees.    MIP40c3-SP66: Events Core Unit DAI Budget (EVENTS-001)   A major event aims to cater to 1200 to 1400 attendees.      MIP40c3-SP66: Events Core Unit DAI Budget (EVENTS-001)   Minor events are to be held at major or minor ETH conferences. A minor event aims to cater to 300 to 400 attendees. I think it’s fair to assume 5% of them might have open up vaults so 405 - 810 users. But as the minimum vault size is big, reducing it to 50% so around 202-405 users. Applying 80-20 rule, I am going to assume top 40-80 of these users have the same as the rest. And we are going to assume minimum at 30k Dai vault each. So 4,860,000 Dai -9,720,000 Dai for the rest and if combined, it’s  9,720,000 to 19,440,000 Dai. But then this will likely to be higher as vaults’ size increases dramatically as it goes up. So doubling it would give 19,440,000 to 38,880,000 Dai minted. There’s also likelihood of potential large RWA or institutional vault user via this kind of event that would end up larger Dai minted. So taking a higher end of the range estimate seems reasonable. So I would support Event Core Unit with the current budget and vote Yes if presented. However, will continue to encourage the team for ways to reduce the cost while increasing the impact. content.content: But like any votes, happy to change my mind if my assumptions or reasoning is flawed.
Welcome to McKinsey and Co., ser.

What about the impact on MKR price? What about the lucky tail-ends, like some high-impact decision maker being positively influenced because they know Maker or were at an event? What about the value of running experiments? Calculations like this are very useful but the caveat is that they don’t tell the full story. And it’s almost a research project in its own right to come up with good models. I’m a fan as long as we are aware of the limitations. For example: Maker is notoriously un-memeable today. If it’s our strategy to push efforts towards changing this, it may easily be a “gradually then suddenly” thing. You will see no results until the dam breaks and then the impact is suddenly massive. This is why strategy matters, and within that frame we’d want to try and measure things while (1) recognizing the areas that are not included in the calculation and (2) recognizing that there are diminishing returns on more and more complicated models in themselves. At one point it becomes better (cheaper, massively more accurate) to just run an experiment rather than to make too many assumptions in too complex prediction models. Numbers are good, but let’s not make the mistake to think that they capture everything. In some situations they are the most reliable method. The methodology itself and its limitations need however be explicitly stated or we run the risk of being blindly reductionist. The other typical misconception is that numbers are more scientific because they are exact. The scientific approach is about hypothesis, repeatable experiments and validation. A numerical model that isn’t tested, may be way more unscientific than principled reasoning without quantification. And the way to test it is to run experiments… just saying. It’s entirely possible that the numeric assumptions are all wrong, and no calculation may be better than a misleading calculation. Note: I have not looked into the details of this CU, so this isn’t a recommendation for or against. I just wanted to comment on the “calculate everything” approach.

content.content: With the Events CU going to a vote soon, I would like to re-iterate the reasons why I think this is a good use of funds as I know it’s hard to follow everything on here.  DAIvinity has been the culmination of cross-CU collaboration that was initiated at ETH Lisbon in October 2021. It was observed that our brand presence at the 2 previous conferences was virtually non-existent. You would not know we are the largest DeFi protocol. We wanted to change that. Work began on DAIvinity in November. Denver was to be the trial run for the new team, and I will say they knocked it out of the park. People at the event were blown away. Quotes I heard were “this was the best crypto event ever” and “this is a rAAVE-level event”. David Hoffman (who later invited us onto Bankless podcast) said it all with his quote “Maker is cool again”. Andrew Burban at ETH Rio said everyone was asking when the next DAIvinity is. We are a hot commodity in the minds of crypto-folks. This is a good thing. I would like to address some of the concerns I heard come up:  What is the benefit of these events? Branding, branding, branding. We have the whos-who of the crypto elite, influencers, devs, other protocol teams in a room for 4-5 hours staring at Maker and DAI branded visuals while they have the time of their lives. This will lead to positive association and ultimately partnerships.  We need a marketing plan first Growth has stated the to-be formed Maker Brand team will not be dealing with the conference event side of things. I think this is smart. This frees them up to focus soley on our user-facing side. Promoting Maker products along with DAI. The Events CU can focus not just on DAIvinity, but also eventually expanding to cover all things involved with in-person events. Sponsorships, hackathons, etc.  Can we do this with less spend? Absolutely. We have already received many requests to co-sponsor this event from Maker-aligned partners such as Oasis and DeFi Saver. We are confident that the sticker price can be halved through co-sponsorship with Maker retaining full creative control. @PonJerry has provided a breakdown with actual expected costs. We need to be prepared to pay for the whole thing, but as a KPI delegates can track from event to event and see how much was saved. Excess funds can be returned to the surplus buffer right after the event is settled. There is always the option to adjust the budget later to reduce the number and/or size of the events in the future.  Can we use another structure than a CU? The options of running this under another CU, contractor or SPF were all discussed. I’ll run over the reasons why we felt a new CU was the best choice available. Running under Growth CU was originally discussed, but this is not really their mandate and it would cause overhead for @Nadia and her already overworked team. Due to the frequency of the events, @Leggevents and @PonJerry need to commit full time to make this happen. Each event requires 2-3 months of up front planning. Both of these guys have full time jobs that they will need to quit, so they need certainty that they will get paid. This is not conducive to a contractor or SPF setup. The SPF in particular requires 2 months for > 50k, so this requires a 5-6 month lead time before the event, but sometimes it’s hard to determine which events will be good candidates that far in advance. For example, ETH Amsterdam was not clear to be a big event until around mid-Feb. A new Events CU was landed on as the best option possible. Furthermore I personally think this Events CU should be expanded in the future to cover all in-person event stuff such that this slack is not being picked up by other CUs.  Freeing up other CUs Related to the spend I want to emphasize that by not hiring this team, the work will once again fall on other CUs to pick up the slack. This saves work hours of other teams to focus on what their mandate is.  Summary DAIvinity has been a successful experiment. Let’s continue the multi-front effort that is pushing Maker and DAI back into the spotlight. I worry that by not passing this proposal we will be destroying all the progress made so far. It’s time to step on the gas instead of the brake. LFG!
